ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: i became better at speaking and presenting.

I grew significantly in my Spanish fluency, pronunciation, and vocabulary. I also learned about the arts and literature in Spanish-speaking countries which was extremely interesting. I had learned about the Theatre of the Absurd in high school, and being able to explore that particular genre of drama in a Spanish context was engaging and entertaining.
I don't think that my Spanish skills were improved that much in this course. I brushed up on old topics I learned from high school but that is it.
I was able to talk more fluently in Spanish and learned more vocabulary.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: Major weakness: You spend no class time on any of the grammatical material that's on exams. Go to class just for attendance, weekly memorization presentations feel like waste of time and useless.
Weaknesses: Too grammar focused and we were left to learn a lot of the concepts ourselves
Strengths are I learned to become a lot more fluid.

The resources of this course (the textbook, online exercises, activities, etc.) were extremely helpful in aiding and increasing my learning of the Spanish language. Our verbal engagement in class also drastically increased my comfortability speaking Spanish and my pronunciation. The organization of the course, however, was often lacking. I would frequently attend class and be confused or surprised by what we were doing because it was unclear based on the syllabus.

One weakness of this course is that they give a lot of busywork. A lot of the work is not valuable to learning Spanish and I found myself rushing through it to get to the next assignment because it wasn't teaching me anything. I also did not like that much of this course felt self-taught and the class felt like it didn't have any structure. In class, our professor would just tell us to talk to each other without any further instruction. I didn't like how we didn't learn any grammar structures in class and instead were expected to teach ourselves advanced grammar structures. Overall, I think that this class needs much more structure and less busy work.

A strength is that it focuses on all areas of language such as writing, speaking, and reading. It also teaches you a lot of vocabulary. It could be improved by having a stricter in class time schedule or plan.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: No. It is a heavy workload already as 1.5 credits but having no type of learning of the material in the classroom makes it so much harder for no reason.
Overall, yes. The course content and activities helped me learn Spanish to a degree I had never learned in before, yet the lack of organization was often frustrating and confusing.

No, I hated this course. I dreaded going to this course every day and felt like a class I had to get through in order to meet my language requirement. I would recommend a different language to another student. I don't think that I learned much in this class.
I would recommend this course to someone who wants to learn Spanish.
